title: Forever101
author: Forever101
content: Food for thought, is it possible to become a miner in naija supposing say our light just come stable. If u get the financial strength, shae you go enter mining with the continuous cut down of d reward wey miners dey get. If person even get am for mind, shae Niger government go allow people enter the business without Dem give them trouble. Wetting go be d future of Bitcoin mining for naija in  the world.

comments.author: Charles-Tim
comments.body: United States is generating the highest bitcoin mining hashrates and miners there are make some money. Electricity cost in Nigeria is cheaper. Cost of living in Nigeria is cheaper. With constant electricity, mining bitcoin will likely give better return in Nigeria.If bitcoin mining reward halved, likely the price of bitcoin will increase in a way that miners will still make some profits.But the bad electricity in the country discourage Nigerians to mine. Check this site:https://worldpopulationreview.com/country-rankings/bitcoin-mining-by-countryOut of 56 countries listed in accordance to the percentage of bitcoin mining hashrates they are generating, Nigeria is not among while the countries with the lowest percentage on the list are generating 0.01% of the total hashrates each. I can not advice anyone to mine in our country.Quote from: Forever101 on October 31, 2023, 06:47:41 PMWetting go be d future of Bitcoin mining for naija in  the world. Why asked this question? Is it because of what Germany Chancellor, Olaf Scholz said recently during his visit in Aso Rock? Germany to provide cheap electricity to Nigeria, other ECOWAS countriesThinking electricity in Nigeria will be good? What I think is that Nigerians prefer to just invest and trade in bitcoin instead. There are some miners in Nigeria, but they are not many and the hashrates geneted is very small. But maybe if electricity would be better in Nigeria, there may be changes, but this will only be a speculation which can be either right or wrong.

comments.body: Before you posted this, I was doing a research on this topic to examine the feasibility and profitability of Bitcoin mining in Nigeria. From my finding, the major expenses for Bitcoin mining is that of equipment and electricity. As soon as the hardwares and other gadgets are secured, electricity becoemes the major constraint. A greater part of Nigeria is still battling with epileptic power supply and this has placed a huge financial burden on businesses especially in the urban centres. Fortunately, there is a part of Nigeria where electricity is constant and free of charge, meaning people don't pay for electricity as it is supplied free of charge by the oil companies. I'm referring to Ogba/Egbama/Ndoni local government area that share boundaries with Imo State, Bayelsa State and Delta State. This is a part of Nigeria rich in oil and gas deposit and playing host to multinational oil giants like Shell, Total Energies, Agip and Adax. These companies built gas turbines that supplies electricity to their host communities as part of their cooperate social responsibilities. Situating a Bitcoin mining rig in this area will solve the energy demand of Bitcoin mining. Apart from this, other cost such as rent is very cheap compared to the urban areas. Indeed there is huge prospect for Bitcoin mining in Nigeria and I intend embarking on this businesses when I have completed my comprehensive feasibility studies of this and also raise the funds needed to start. However,  I'm still contrained by the distance from the city where I live to this area that is at the outskirt of Rivers State. Nevertheless,  I will find a way around it when I'm ready to start.Quote from: Charles-Tim on October 31, 2023, 08:40:05 PMThinking electricity in Nigeria will be good? What I think is that Nigerians prefer to just invest and trade in bitcoin instead. There are some miners in Nigeria, but they are not many and the hashrates geneted is very small. But maybe if electricity would be better in Nigeria, there may be changes, but this will only be a speculation which can be either right or wrong.If there is any way I can consult you in this, I will do that. I need all the technical advice I can get to start mining Bitcoin in the place I mentioned. Each time I visit those areas I mentioned, I feel electricity is wasting already.  A lot of things are cheap in those areas... with $1500 land is secured, there is free edible water and the foods are natural and mostly grown within. I know it will cost some funds to start and that I'm already working on but I need all the technical knowledge I can get to start already.

Light, money and the mining rig aren't the only challenge thst a miner can face when establishing a mining rig, setting up one is very time and money effective, this means you will require money to be a miner, yet this is not the most challenging aspect of it, there are many miners across the world all struggling in solving the complex mathematics equations and only the first to finish result in being awarded it's reward which is bitcoin, how versatile are you going to be among the thousands competing for same bitcoin reward in miming, how technically inclined are you in understanding about bitcoin mining, think about all these before considering starting a mining rig.

If you join a mining pool, the reward is shared based on the mining hashrates each miners that connect to the mining pool are generating. There are common mining pools that a miner can join their pools and receive bitcoin as the mining pool is able to mine a block.

Others don talk well here but make I throw mouth too for the matter, I go answer your question one after another so e no go dey complicated to read.1: Yes it's possible to become a miner anywhere wey Bitcoin activity aren't officially banned. The mining activity can also be done legally or illegal too if to say the government dun ban am although I no go advice this one to avoid jail time.2: The cult down in mining reward (wey be Bitcoin block reward) dey benefits miners in long time so this one no suppose be excuse why you no go mine, assuming every other factors dey okay. The current block reward na 6.25 Bitcoin wey miners dey share so make we just do a rough estimate say Bitcoin na $35k which means that 6.25 BTC = $218k+ then after the halving the reward come reduced to 3.125 and Bitcoin is trading at a minimum of $100k, e mean say the new reward is worth (3.125x$100k) $312k+ also if the miners been hodl the Bitcoin dem be received when Bitcoin reward was 6.25 dem dun get profits too and one certain thing wey dey na say the price of Bitcoin is program to increase after every halving based on the concept of demand and supply.  No forget too the transaction fees wey miners dey receive in addition to block reward. 3/4: (I go combine both last questions make my post no too plenty), the government never talk anytime bad against mining so doing it isn't illegal and if the government noticed an increase dem fit tax those running the business and make their own choppings or freestyle dem provided dem they pay for electricity dem dey consume. The only time a government go dey against Bitcoin mining na when dem dey against Bitcoin. Nigeria no get future for mining because no matter as you talk there's more profits in Hodling Bitcoin than mining and you know we only go where the money is made more. Put all those money wey you wan use set up a mining farm into Bitcoin and just HODL and see the results. Wetin I dey talk na say e no go become a popular thing.
